item.title: R-AESPE-1
item.description: The idea of proof There are different types of proof, legal, scientific/medical (experimental?), mathematical, etc. The first two proof are judgements based on probability and not absolute statements.

item.title: R-AESPE-2
item.description: Sets of Numbers First section of Chapter 6 in Cambridge (pg 44-42?) There are many proofs Direct proofs Proof by contradiction Proof by exhaustion Proof by contrapositive Proof by induction Sets of numbers have symbols

item.title: R-AESPE-3
item.description: Proofs Always just assume the conditional part of the statement Funny Spec words This is in “the realm of logic”

item.title: R-AESPE-4
item.description: Quantifiers These are words or symbols which specify the quantity or existence of something in a mathematical statement. e.g. All square numbers are positive.

item.title: R-AESPE-5
item.description: Combinatorics 1 Multiplication Principle If there are m ways of performing 1 task and n ways of performing another task, then there are $m \times n$ ways of performing both tasks.
